en.proyecto-6-p: Data Science project focused on building several advanced models capable of predicting the survival probability of Titanic passengers. It includes a complete pipeline: exploratory analysis, data cleaning, feature engineering, and modeling with XGBoost, achieving highly stable performance through cross-validation (RMSE ‚âà 0.056). The image below shows the top performing models found for this problem and the most relevant survival features. en.proyecto-7-p: Project aimed at identifying risk patterns and predicting the probability of accidents using advanced data science and machine learning techniques. The work includes data cleaning and normalization, deep exploratory analysis, feature engineering based on human, environmental, and operational factors, and the construction of predictive models capable of anticipating incidents with high precision. The main objective is to support preventive decision-making through models that allow prioritizing alerts, optimizing security resources, and reducing critical events. This project demonstrates my ability to transform complex data into actionable information and develop solutions that provide real value in security and risk prevention contexts.
en.proyecto-7-p-2: Below are two representative images of the project: the first shows a comparison of the predictive models used, highlighting their performance and precision in accident prediction. The second image illustrates the most influential factors contributing to accident occurrence, providing key insights for prevention and risk mitigation. **Residual Analysis** ensures the model is robust. The normal, zero-centered error distribution rules out systematic biases (e.g., risk underestimation), which is vital for critical decision-making.
